articles.headline: The Flash Crash, in Miniature
articles.snippet: Since the so-called flash crash in May, some stocks have had mini flash crashes, which could foretell a new plunge.
articles.abstract: Since the so-called flash crash in May, some stocks have had mini flash crashes, which could foretell a new plunge.
articles.lead_paragraph: BlackBerrys were buzzing inside Progress Energy in Raleigh, N.C.: in a blink, the 102-year-old utility had been virtually wiped out on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Company Accused of Firing Over Facebook Post
articles.snippet: The National Labor Relations Board said a company fired an employee illegally after she criticized her supervisor.
articles.abstract: The National Labor Relations Board said a company fired an employee illegally after she criticized her supervisor.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what labor officials and lawyers view as a ground-breaking case involving workers and social media, the National Labor Relations Board has accused a company of illegally firing an employee after she criticized her supervisor on her Facebook page.

articles.headline: At Legal Fringe, Empty Houses Go to the Needy
articles.snippet: Hundreds of vacated houses in Florida are being claimed by strangers citing a law from the 1800s.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of vacated houses in Florida are being claimed by strangers citing a law from the 1800s.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Save Florida Homes Inc. and its owner, Mark Guerette, have found foreclosed homes for several needy families here in Broward County, and his tenants could not be more pleased. Fabian Ferguson, his wife and two children now live a two-bedroom home they have transformed from damaged and abandoned to full and cozy.
articles.byline: By Catharine Skipp and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Repeal of ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Faces Struggle in Congress
articles.snippet: The repeal of the policy faces new uncertainties as time runs out for the Senate and objections remain among Republicans and the senior ranks of the military.
articles.abstract: The repeal of the policy faces new uncertainties as time runs out for the Senate and objections remain among Republicans and the senior ranks of the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prospects for Congress to authorize repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy face new uncertainties as time runs out for the Senate to act and strong objections remain among Republicans and the most senior ranks of the military.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Flier Patience Wears Thin at Checkpoints
articles.snippet: The government is facing growing criticism from travel industry groups over the escalating security measures for airline passengers.
articles.abstract: The government is facing growing criticism from travel industry groups over the escalating security measures for airline passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Transportation Security Administration scrambles to address vulnerabilities in procedures for screening cargo, it is facing growing criticism from travel industry groups over the escalating security measures for passengers.

articles.headline: Low Rates Hurt Bonds for Housing
articles.snippet: Housing projects used the interest they earned on spare cash to help them pay off their bonds, but those earnings have now shrunk.
articles.abstract: Housing projects used the interest they earned on spare cash to help them pay off their bonds, but those earnings have now shrunk.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not just retired savers who are struggling with a sharp reduction in their investment income as interest rates hover near zero. Hundreds of affordable housing projects across the country are feeling the pain, too.
